text: Just a quick reminder that there is one week left. Any contributions to any Gitcoin Grants project will be matched by their CLR fund, and there are lots of interesting projects. Also, my shameless plug for ethers.js: https://t.co/s7t0ujjfWx

@peter_szilagyi @VitalikButerin What type of structures will need serialization in Eth2? I believe in Eth1, RLP is only used for array of 6 or 9 data items (pre-155 unsigned tx calculation and signed tx) and array of 2 data items (contract address calculation). No nesting req’d.

@peter_szilagyi @VitalikButerin Is it used in calculating stateRoot? Or only for local node storage? My interest is from implementing libraries like ethers.js; where there are already so many serialization encodings needed, each slightly incompatible with each other. Does the standard ABI encoding not suffice?
@kyletorpey Le sigh... So at some point soon, we’ll see one raise even more and begin to have a negative network value? :)
@nicksdjohnson I think a lot of those sites use some sort of “super cookie”, because these days, even in Safari Private Mode, they still limit me...

@gakonst @jasoncarver I so very much want create2 though, to replace my one-time keyless transaction craziness (which allows off-chain bytecode verification, btw) for the Firefly Multisig… There seems to be a similar attack surface with proxy contracts already, anyways. Create2 can be used as safely.

@gakonst Given the fact we have access to only a finite number of particles in the universe to make memory and processors out of, there is no actually Turing-Complete physical machine, so all algorithms are really O(1). :)

@technocrypto @gakonst I had exactly you in mind when I changed my original “…there are only a finite number of particles…” to “…we only have access to a finite number of particles…”; I can certainly imagine a person being able to imagine a universe with infinite computation though. :)

@NoahZinsmeister That’s an interesting idea. I cannot think of anyway it would be possible today with an Ethereum node but with a VM, you could emulate the execution in-browser, using the real blockchain as the data source. The normal consistency caveats would apply, but it’d basically work. :)
@peter_szilagyi Awesome! Does that mean it will have native Firefly (@hi_firefly) support? The Open Source, Air-Gapped DIY Hardware Wallet for Ethereum? :)

@nicksdjohnson @CoinbaseWallet @ethstatus @imTokenOfficial @Alpha_Wallet Is EIP-712 ready? I haven’t added it to ethers yet b/c (last I checked) it was overly complex, while also not expressive enough, requiring non-trivial work since it is completely different from existing encodings and didn’t even solve the problem as it isn’t machine-readable… :(

@nicksdjohnson @CoinbaseWallet @ethstatus @imTokenOfficial @Alpha_Wallet And I may just not understand the use-case yet; if it’s non-recoverable, a string message seems sufficient for most authentication, where as if it is recoverable, it can be both machine-readable to scripts/contracts and human-readable in a UI. I’m thinking more format string-ish.
@liamihorne It’s license isn’t compatible to be included in ethers as a dependency, but it should be fairly easy to use it in tandem. :)

@nicksdjohnson Wow. They must have pre-scheduled updates? It’d be awesome if the hash of the update was already known too, and any changes to updates would have to reference the originally scheduled hash. A blockchain with a “next blockhash” in the header, of sorts... :)

@evabeylin Love this idea. If there was a reputation score that showed up on your profile with which to scale showing up in other’s feeds, which people could bid their own for or against. Hard to protect from Sybil entities though... :(
@nicksdjohnson Especially since a hostile takeover can result in arbitrary financial gains, making an attack not only affordable, but actually incentivize it...

@EvanKeast I always just wanted it to be “app”. Decentralization should be a core feature sought after by the developer as much as an end user and not a marketing verb. We don’t call mobile apps mapps or web apps wapps...

@pldespaigne @_jefflau @ensdomains Keep in mind events can only tell you half the story. More interesting resolvers can do more interesting things, such as change the address based on the timestamp or the website URL based on state from another contract, which may not trigger events.

Ahoy! My latest article is up! It’s a simple money-potting technique for secretly bribing attackers to accidentally reveal they have your mnemonic phrase, tentatively called SQRL-ing. Replies with animated squirrel and squirrel-related GIFs appreciated. :) https://t.co/Jkzofi2KN1

@BenDMahala @evan_van_ness What is Vault? Link? :) Even if popular, an attacker won’t “know”. Brute-forcing (CPU time) could easily cost more than the probability of a SQRL * payout, so are still incentivized to steal. In the event of multiple attackers (public leak), stealing is the only viable option. :)
Has anyone recently (in the last few months) synced Geth? How long (ish) did it take and what are the current disk space requirements? Interested in both with and without tracing…

@gregthegreek @dani__ivanov It’s just a Mac Mini, with a few extra terabytes of 1,050 MB/s hard drives. It’s mainly for local backups and keeping a synced local node. Hopefully it will make it easier to add WebSocket and Clef support to ethers too, as well as dumping the live tx pool data I need mined. :)

@BenDMahala @evan_van_ness Ah, I see; I didn’t realize Vault was already a popularized term. The FireflyVault also uses time-locks extensively, along with multisig. But SQRL-ing works with it too as well as recovery keys. At the end of the day, what will make it awesome is if the UX is straight forward. :)

@nicksdjohnson @paddypisa @danfinlay @IAmNickDodson Yeah. That’s kinda how I see it, except instead of a bare proxy, I expect the “average wallet” that people use to be a contract wallet, in which case all that proxy-like functionality can be there. Rich transactions may also be able to trivialize parts of a meta-tx too...

So much indoors, so little excuse to not be strange. Hence, Rooted: far-too-easy-to-upgrade Ethereum contracts. Send bytecode to `v0.rooted.eth` to deploy. Self-destruct and send new bytecode? Deployed to the same great address but with brand new code. :) https://t.co/9cXbejdYHT
@hudsonjameson A little from column A and a little from column B...
@gregthegreek @hudsonjameson @JHancock Ah yes! Counting nibbles rather than bytes? :)
@gregthegreek @hudsonjameson @JHancock For a keccak256? Yes... Why? :p

@nanexcool Yuppers! Pass `blockTag` as an override parameter. Keep in mind that many public backends may disregard it; for example, the non-paid INFURA backend will silently ignore the block tag in calls. If you have archive access to INFURA or your own node, it will work fine though. :)

@trent_vanepps @gitcoin @ethersproject (I didn’t even know the broadcast feature existed; two other grants I previously funded did it to me first, so I went hunting for the feature. I’ll also be contributing again to both of those projects. ;))

@mudgen So, there is a “solution”, which is forwarding data that needs to survive to the storage.rooted.eth contract. It combines the caller (your contract’s address) and a key you provide. It adds an extra 800 gas per read and write though and is a bit clunky… https://t.co/83KB5g7goU

Shameless Plug Alert: These odd weekend projects help keep ethers tested and full-featured. Dogfooding ftw! Anyhoo, it’s the latest GitCoin CLR and even tiny 1 DAI contributions go a long way. Bonus points for amounts based on nerdy references. Thanks! :)  https://t.co/s7t0ujjfWx
@mudgen That will revert. The create2 opcode won’t deploy a contract if there is already something living there. :)

@nanexcool Also any valid ethers blockTag can be used. A block number, tags like "latest" and "earliest" and a negative number will indicate that many blocks ago (so if the current block number is 1000, the blockTag`-1` will use 999).

@gregthegreek @hudsonjameson @JHancock I think solidity-hashes.json.gz is what you are looking for. They were generated against an Ethereum node; the generation scripts are buried in the package somewhere too. :) https://t.co/qPBeFGU6OZ
@eviljordan (also the use case you are describing is exactly why they were built into Ethereum; so it can play well with others :))

@Amxx Unfortunately, you cannot. SELFDESTRUCT only schedules a contract for removal *immediately after* the transaction completes. A contract cannot be destroyed and recreated (even using CREATE2) within the same transaction. This restriction is part of the skinny create specification.

@JayeHarrill @nicksdjohnson @VitalikButerin @realLedgerwatch @antiprosynth But CREATE2 is largely irrelevant in this case. The only opcode you care about is SELFDESTRUCT. If you use the DAI contract and it can SELFDESTRUCT you will be unhappy regardless of if/what any new code looks like. Also proxies, freezables and ownables should be red-ish flags. :)

@nicksdjohnson @JayeHarrill @realLedgerwatch This I agree with, but could be addressed with better tooling. In fact, Etherscan could even more easily (programmatically) detect a CREATE2 deployment chain than it could (in general) detect a proxy contract and provide a nice little “buyer beware” flare on the contract page. :)

@Chloethedev @JayeHarrill @nicksdjohnson @realLedgerwatch Oh, I completely agree. The number of people who browse the contract code (and would notice security issues) is tiny. If the tools can detect contract code can change, wallets can begin to surface this information. So we want to move to create2 and away from proxies. :)
@realLedgerwatch If you think CREATE2 + SELFDESTRUCT is bad, you’re going to really hate Turing Completeness. :)

@realLedgerwatch Kidding aside, you don’t need to destroy useful operations to gain the type of security you desire. There are ways to guard against much of the malice you are concerned with but I agree tools need to better surface CREATE2 chains and perhaps “deployment audits” should be a thing.

Trust Graphic Novel - "The goal of the project is to grow the global blockchain community in the locations where people’s lives will be most transformed by the impact - in developing countries." https://t.co/WJApFfkc8h

@JayeHarrill But at this step it is important to note that a CREATE2 contract is machine detectable as a contract that *can* change. A code audit would reveal this. Tools could reveal this. Changing code *cannot* be stopped, *by definition* of Turing completeness…
@eviljordan SHA256 is available in Solidity, as is RIPEMD160, both of which you will need. Bitcoin uses SHA256d most places (for good reason), but that’s just SHA256 twice. :)
@eviljordan Not really. They are both precompiles built into Ethereum, so they should be quite affordable. :)

Several grants specifically target injustice present in this system. Since bonds are returned, your donations are recycled many times per year, which keeps people out of jail, their lives on-track, and prevents innocent people from falsely admitting to crimes just to avoid jail.

For those unfamiliar with the bail system, how it works, its effects and consequences, and how terrible it is, I highly recommend watching this short YouTube video by @iamjohnoliver. https://t.co/2aaS4ORSOo

@nicksdjohnson @JayeHarrill @VitalikButerin @realLedgerwatch @antiprosynth More importantly, makes them “highly problematic” in a way that isn’t still achievable in an equally problematic way with the described changes. Breaking functionality to solve a problem with a solution that doesn’t solve the problem doesn’t help anyone. :)

@JayeHarrill Yeah. Where did this new animosity for CREATE2 come from? All the exact attack vectors people seem concerned with exist without it. I’ll repost this up to show some CREATE2 love though. :) https://t.co/9cXbejdYHT
Black Girls CODE - "Through community outreach programs such as workshops and after school programs, we introduce underprivileged girls to basic programming skills." https://t.co/KiHyS8I9JE

Only a couple days left of this Gitcoin round and rather than list all the random grants I supported, I wanted to focus on just a few, which I think are more important, especially these days. The overarching theme is diversity and seeking equality. Let me know if I missed any. :)

@JayeHarrill I mean, well before day 0. We already had a blockchain that wasn’t Turing Complete: BTC. That was the entire point of Ethereum, to build a Turing Complete blockchain. I think many people underestimate what Turing Completeness means, but that’s what we got, so day 0 we decided. :)

@JayeHarrill …so, the focus has to be on audits or other out-of-band processes. Removing self-destruct (or CREATE2) does not improve the system regarding your concerns *at all* and in fact makes it worse. We need better tooling, and ways to enable tooling to be better. :)
@thegostep I just added answers to your questions. And asked for more context in one case. :)
@Amxx “It should also be noted that SELFDESTRUCT has no immediate effect on nonce or code, thus a contract cannot be destroyed and recreated within one transaction.” https://t.co/3aKgpKBZfV

@_prestwich @realLedgerwatch I don’t disagree, I’ve implemented the EVM a few times. Maybe something yellowpaper-ish with clearly defined edge-case behaviour would help? I littered Ropsten w/ so many tests to figure out CREATE2+SELFDESTRUCT. Better docs is a better solution than nuking useful functionality…
@Amxx Not sure if you saw rooted.eth, but I use it for deploying my ParkingResolver for my ENS names. So, less than production, but production-esque. :) https://t.co/9cXbejdYHT
"The Bail Project National Revolving Bail Fund is a critical tool to prevent incarceration and combat racial and economic disparities in the bail system"; 10,730 bails to-date https://t.co/8LJKJQrumn

@JayeHarrill What does flagged mean in this case and what would a node do once they were flagged? I think we’re getting off-topic. The goal of the mentioned removal of self-destruct has nothing to do with mutability and more to do with effort to reduce *client* complexity, as I understand. :)

@eviljordan Are you trying to verify a BTC tx or a prefixed "\x18Bitcoin Signed Message:" message? The EC math is the same. The difference is in the HASH160 address calculation; ETH is KECCAk256[12:] while BTC is RIPEMD160(SHA256d). But Ethereum supports all these algos, so it is doable… :)
@eviljordan I’ve never tried this, but it should absolutely be possible. How is providing the r, s, v "cheating" though? You definitely need those to verify a signature; that *is* the signature. :)

@Amxx I feel you… It still works for many things, as long as you can live without your contract on chain momentarily. But certainly, for some things it’s a no-go. If you pay a high gas price you can *prolly* get your contract upgraded in back-to-back transactions in a block… hmm… :)
@Amxx Sounds similar to diamonds? https://t.co/6zBtNwcecQ

@eviljordan …and for most purposes the HASH160 is probably good enough, any UI can compute the Base58Check easy enough. If you want to return the string Base58 address from the contract, that’s doable too, but a bit more work. :)

@JayeHarrill @nicksdjohnson @VitalikButerin @realLedgerwatch @antiprosynth But that attack vector already 100% exists even without CREATE2 or SELFDESTRUCT (e.g. proxy contracts). Code behaviour can change. With Lurch, I can do this today with only STATICCALL allowing arbitrary code updates w/ a static address. It’s a consequence of Turing Completeness…

@nicksdjohnson @VitalikButerin @realLedgerwatch @antiprosynth I agree with strongly oppose. Many contracts use a proxy pattern, which is a less-efficient way to mimic nearly the exact same functionality (and threat model) that people seem concerned with here. Unless we remove DELEGATECALL too. We can also fix reentrancy by nixing *CALL… :)

For those curious about the EIP1193Bridge; it wraps an ethers Provider/Signers and exposes them via the EIP-1193 interface, allowing you to use them more easily in Web3.js and other libraries designed for EIP-1193. You can use ethers under-the-covers for non-ethers libraries… :)

@Amxx @pedrouid All built-in signers support it though. If you wrote a custom signer, you will have to opt-in by implementing the TypedDataSigner interface and implementing it in your sub-class. It’s not as experimental as the NonceManager, since it is fully available in the core library. :)

@_Dave__White_ @Timidan_x @BlockEnthusiast You can choose a completely random signature, which will have *an* address when you use ec-recover. So, even though it appears to have signed something, there is no private key. But a private key can sign any number of things, all of which will ec-recover to the same address. :)
@gakonst Ethers has the JsonRpcBatchProvider which implicitly batches things that occur during the same event loop. Sometimes people ask questions about it, so *someone* is using it. :)

@_prestwich @_Dave__White_ @BlockEnthusiast Exactly how I anti-comfort people who ask “what if two different people get the same private key”; the odds are much better that you’ll get the same address. Fortunately, the (lack of) energy in the available universe mitigates most of these concerns. :)

@nicksdjohnson @_Dave__White_ @BlockEnthusiast If you used just one, it could be a random signature (à la one-time keyless transactions), which will ec-recover to *something*. If you have two, you know there exists a private key out there, so it is an actual EOA that can do actual transactions. :)

Luckily, we don't need to sit on our hands until we have it on a platter from the EF. In the meantime, we can be working on short-lived single and multi-client testnets. These are great stepping stones towards the 🏆testnet and major achievements on their own.  8/n

1/ There has been a lot of discussion around "leadership" in Ethereum 2.0 this past week, much around the lack of it. I tend to see it the other way. Ethereum is strong because of abundant, world-class leadership.
Hear, hear!

The EF are designing the specification and they will most likely produce the test vectors, so ultimately, we're waiting on research to mature. That being said, it's our job as implementers to help them and we'll be doing so! 💪 7/n

We've been focused on optimizing sync times and have seen lots of improvement. Here's a little recap on what I can remember from recent history 👇

Into the Ether returns this week!

That trade-off is configurable at the CLI, so users can choose if they'd just like to sync fast and don't care about fast access to historical info (e.g., validators), or if they don't care about syncing but want fast access to history (e.g., block explorers).

As a result of these optimizations, we're seeing Lighthouse syncing a 16k validator, production spec network at somewhere between 6-20 blocks/second.

6 b/s is what our t2.medium AWS nodes do and 20 b/s is what my flashy desktop does.

We're still improving too!

There's also been tons of work happening in the networking stack and the rest of the client; all the core team have been doing amazing work.

On top of the actual dev work we're also interviewing Rust developers, preparing RFCs for GUIs and scheduling our security review.

Last week we released a v0.1.1 release, but a bit hastily. One of the database optimizations didn't play well with our fork choice algorithm and we saw testnet instability. A bunch of validators started producing on weird forks and we lost finality several times.
The Herumi library looks like its ~2x faster than our native Rust library, and we're not even using it yet. We're saving that one for later.

If you're a Rust developer, check our Twitter for the job offering.

If you're a UI/UX designer, check for our validator GUI RfP. 

If you're a contracting devops pro, DM me directly because I need help launching testnets.

If you have questions, feel free to ask :)

In fact, we never actually lose historical information. Instead, it takes longer for us to retrieve that information. 

So, we have a trade-off between syncing fast and retrieving historical information fast.

I'm really looking forward to reading the results of this. I can't wait to see what they find.

Congrats to the research team for getting to this point!
Thanks for having me @econoar and @sassal0x!

I think Herumi will be very helpful because roughly 50% of our block processing time is signature verification. 
Another ~30% is merkle-hashing the beacon state and other ~15% is just doing memcopy of the beacon state and all it's caches.

Additionally, he's integrated the super-fast, hand-written assembly BLS library by Herumi.

We already know how we can get rid of that memcopy, we just need to get around to doing it. There's honestly so much going on that there's low-hanging fruit we haven't yet picked.

I think we can drop those state hashing times too, but that's no so low-hanging.

The new fork choice algorithm is up to 40x faster in some areas! Adding a new block to it takes literally microseconds now. Finding the head takes less than a millisecond on my laptop.

Reminder! if you operate eth1 Görli node for eth2's pyrmont testnet, please upgrade to Berlin ASAP. Görli Berlin fork is in 5 days ⌛️

We've fixed:

* A frequent crash occurring on certain hardware configurations 

* Long processing delays triggered by the reception of attestations that reference already pruned states

* A LibP2P peer management issue

* An occasional false-positive in doppelganger detection
Görli Berlin fork is tomorrow. Don't forget to upgrade your nodes!

New features include:

* A new improved format of the slashing protection database which significantly reduces the disk load when running a large number of validators (1000+).

* Automatic configuration of external IP address when a public IP address is used

Other notable additions/improvements include:

- Nightly builds for the very adventurous
 
- REST API endpoints: /eth/v1/beacon/pool/attestations & /api/eth/v1/validator/aggregate_and_proofs

- A fix to false positive doppelganger detections on fast restarts

P.S. A friendly reminder that if you're running Nimbus with a version prior to 1.0.10 (March 2021) you are exposed to a vulnerability in our core cryptography library (this library is used by all eth2 clients).  If this concerns you, please update as soon as you can.

@GuthL @Bloxy_info But, verifying new full blocks on the side would take slightly longer and while this is being done an empty block might be used as a proxy, so yes. Practically, a reasonable miner could run a few block producers in parallel that would prepare blocks at 0M, 2M, 4M and so on...

@SchalkDormehl @3esmit @3esmit refers to a fast sync. If you need archive sync with historical states then this would take days and a few TB. But fast sync with one switcy (to download block bodies) is enough to rebuild the full archive from downloaded data.
@GuthL @Bloxy_info You cannot calculate a new state root if you do not know the whole state. When changing the miner's account balance you need to change the whole tree path.

@econoar @SavantSpecter @VitalikButerin @DAppNode It has been open since we had seen the DAppNode demo on GoerliCon in January. Limited resources, but definitely something we would love to have https://t.co/Cj3ZTzHF3V

@SavantSpecter @econoar @VitalikButerin Yes, a great article discussing Parity sync modes. Nethermind fast sync config for mainnet is similar to Parity 'fast - ancient'. Please note that the chain sizes in the article are from a long time ago and no longer representing the chain size properly. Relative sizes are good.

@GuthL @Bloxy_info Also, an edge case scenario - when given a choice between two sibling blocks to pick one of them as a parent for a new block, a reasonable miner can prefer an empty one while verifying the 10M one. This should happen very rarely.
@GuthL @Bloxy_info Because of the miner reward changing the state, miners need a fully verified block to build a new state root no matter whether they are mining an empty block or a full one.

@GuthL @Bloxy_info Were we not looking at the increase since the gas limit was raised to 10M? Additional 2M gas must be 10ms for miners or less. I think that a few things contribute here - slightly longer block verification, slightly longer block preparation, and empty tx pools.

@dotnet There should be some work done to decouple Visual Studio releases from .NET Core releases. With more dependencies coming (WinForms, WPF, some Windows-related ones) we may end up with .NET Core waiting for a lot of Microsoft products in the future.

@econoar @VitalikButerin Yes, this is just the headers + state and the optional switches in config to download all the bodies and all the receipts. The plan is to make the bodies download by default soon as this is healthier for the network. We prefer to keep the receipts off by default.
@Bloxy_info Empty blocks count should naturally grow with increased gas limits as statistically more often all meaningful transactions will be swiped from the pool.

@barinov Yes, our validator runs on the latest version now. Also, we can assume that this version will transition into Istanbul smoothly (unless any issues discovered during the Ropsten testnet period).
@SchalkDormehl @3esmit Then it is up to you to wait for more fully verified blocks so you can pick an arbitrary security level by waiting for 64, 128, and so on fully verified blocks.
@MitalikButerin @VitalikButerin You can also opt in for body downloads from the beginning - it adds around 60GB of data to the download.

@trent_vanepps @3esmit No trust. Every state entry hash is recalculated so not a single byte of data is entering the DB if not reachable from the state root. Headers are rooted in genesis / not hanging.

@SchalkDormehl @3esmit Our fast sync does download all headers from genesis so there is no trust needed. All state is checked.
If you mean validating every transaction and running the VM for every transaction but not storing the intermediate state (like pruning) then this is not built in Nethermind.

@MitalikButerin @VitalikButerin Best full block: 0 is a log line just after the state sync finished and just before the full blocks were downloaded from the pivot block onwards. At that time there was no full block and the moment later there are 32 latest full blocks.

@GuthL @Bloxy_info Only the last comment at that link is valid and the discussion here brings much more details about what actually is happening. A miner cannot mine a new block without verifying the parent because they will not be able to create a valid state root and they need it before hashing.

@GuthL @Bloxy_info Longer block propagation due to bigger block sizes (more txs included) might be an important factor. However, you were comparing the block propagation changes for EIP-2028 and even significant size changes were not that visible?
@SavantSpecter @econoar @VitalikButerin The defaults here are applied when nothing is in the config file. The mainnet fast sync uses this config file: https://t.co/52BlihWQFH

@SchalkDormehl @3esmit finally you have every single state entry starting from the state root of any of the last 32 blocks with their hashes recalculated so the trie is fully verified. So if you assume that nobody mined more than 32 fake blocks then you are safe from the moment it says it synced (tbc)

@peter_szilagyi @natewelch_ @realLedgerwatch @hudsonjameson @Ivshti I think that by the end of Q2 this argument will no longer be raised. Generally agree that not downloading bodies is not healthy. We will bring something both healthy and super cool soon.
@MPtherealMVP we need the goerlians to gather

@peter_szilagyi @VitalikButerin @natewelch_ @realLedgerwatch @hudsonjameson @Ivshti Anyone can serve the data. As for decentralization - you will still have the traditional way of synchronizing. It is all about providing efficient infrastructure that remains trustless but can step up quickly if someone is willing to pay to save time.

@peter_szilagyi @VitalikButerin @natewelch_ @realLedgerwatch @hudsonjameson @Ivshti We consider to add it as a paid service. We will serve these from cloud where people can download 4TB for X$ and have a full archive node in a day or so. Full archive nodes are obviously targeting corporations / big players and it will save them a lot of money (no 12 days sync).

@peter_szilagyi @natewelch_ @realLedgerwatch @hudsonjameson @Ivshti It is a good experimentation while Geth does support it and we can trust it to remain this way. We still have in plans downloading bodies as a default option (or even not allowing users to not download bodies in fast sync). We have some great ideas to speed it up.

@natewelch_ @realLedgerwatch @hudsonjameson @Ivshti @peter_szilagyi Nethermind allows you to ignore historical receipts entirely when synchronizing. This is actually a default behaviour until you change configuration files. Downloading headers and bodies only gives you a ~100GB full node that can serve full archive nodes on the network.
@GuthL @tkstanczak @mysticryuujin https://t.co/W9YhEG4AlM
https://t.co/ZCSnDvmXYt

@VitalikButerin @peter_szilagyi @natewelch_ @realLedgerwatch @hudsonjameson @Ivshti We also want to add an untrusted DB mode where you just connect a DB and then on each first access you verify consistency. This way we want to serve instant full archive nodes for big corporations and fast sync nodes that can be simply downloaded and launched with delayed checks.

@VitalikButerin @peter_szilagyi @natewelch_ @realLedgerwatch @hudsonjameson @Ivshti You would need to calculate the probability of some block not being held by any of the peers but assuming that you would end up finding it then yes. There are vast improvements possible if the nodes advertise their exact ranges they store.

And while widening highways is a one-time cost, increasing block sizes has a permanent cost: the increased centralization of the network.

Raising the block size makes it more expensive to run a full node, so only large/wealthy entities can do it.
8/

This phenomenon is known as "induced demand"

A slow roadway incentivizes people to seek alternatives such as different forms of transportation or moving closer to work.

When capacity is increased, people are re-incentivized to use that road, and it fills back up again quickly. https://t.co/z8Gj2XsZ2N

@LefterisJP @gregthegreek @SCBuergel @etherscan @POKTnetwork It becomes even more urgent to address the issue as the data becomes larger. If the community relies on service providers, those service providers will naturally, over time, take advantage. Thus, the community must not rely on service providers. @stskeeps @LefterisJP @gregthegreek @SCBuergel @etherscan @POKTnetwork It's easier than that (or at least I hope it is). Chain data is immutable. The extraction of the  index is reproducible, so the index is also immutable. The community verifies each extraction once and publishes IPFS hashes to a smart contract - everyone has the index for free.

@SCBuergel @LefterisJP @etherscan @POKTnetwork Yes. It works. Your 'script' would be simple, but would take MONTHS to run. Same result from TrueBlocks on a desktop in seconds/minutes (hours if there are millions of txs). List all outgoing AND incoing txs with `chifra export address`. Plus it reconciles both ETH and tokens.

@cadamstallard @thegrifft @owocki @gitcoin If your "grandma" sends a connection request over a phone number you don't recognize, don't connect. If you end up with two copies of "grandma," you messed up, so reconnect with grandma over a trusted channel (e.g. face to face), then flag the grandma that didn't come to the top.

@owocki @cadamstallard @thegrifft @gitcoin @UBIpromoter Yes, BrightID nodes come with graph analysis out-of-the-box. You can just query a user and get a "yes" or "no" answer. And as @thegrifft said it really is fun. Way more fun than filling out forms, paying $100 and waiting in line at a post office for someone to take your picture.

Identity has been an elusive challenge in Web3. 

We wrote Demystifying Digital Identity to make the often-confusing topic clearer and more practical: what is ID, what to beware of, what to insist on, & what simple steps to take for your app or service

@owocki @gitcoin Yes,

The best thing that can be done is to not connect to someone who is spoofing someone else.

That name and photo is only shared directly when making a connection; it's not stored on nodes.

When apps use BrightID, they don't see the names and photos of their users.

@owocki @gitcoin Unlike FB, invitations in BrightID don't appear from nowhere. They come through pre-existing trust channels. The most common way to make a connection is face-to-face or video-to-video. Receiving a text from a trusted number is also ok.

2. 🔍 Insight into contract opcount and bytesize

There currently is a protocol-level limit of 201 opcodes and 520 bytes for $BCH contracts. To see how a contract instance conforms to those limits, an `instance.opcount` and `instance.bytesize` has been added. https://t.co/7rD2Vs6kBW

4. 🐛 Bug fixes (both reported by @dagur)
 
- A bug was fixed where incorrect stack calculations occurred when defining multiple variables inside if-statements.
- A bug was fixed where the size of a preimage was not accounted for when in fee calculation for covenants.

3. ⚠️ Warnings when exceeding limits

1. 📅 Date literals

Time checks in BCH use timestamps, but humans are used to working with dates and times. 

The new date literal allows you to specify a date + time which is translated to the correct timestamp by the compiler.

Contributed by @nathanielCheria https://t.co/msCZ2tD9kg

2. 🌐 BitcoinRpcNetworkProvider

Sometimes you want to connect to a node directly (rather than a middleware service like Fulcrum or BCH-JS). 

If that is the case you can now connect to a BCH node directly using the BitcoinRpcNetworkProvider.

Contributed by @BlockpartySh https://t.co/IsXopsgDUc

4. 🐛 Impactful bug fixes (cont'd)

To fix this bug the calculation had to be moved from the compiler to the SDK. 

This means that it is slightly more difficult to use certain covenants outside of the CashScript SDK. 

When using the SDK, usage is still the same.
@BokkyPooBah Better paid 666 ETH for it!

7. 🐫 Migration

v0.5.0 contains a number of breaking changes in the SDK. 

Refer to the release notes (https://t.co/dpjTN3Aeyu) for the full list of changes. 

Refer to the migration notes (https://t.co/s7SFcpNFxd) for the steps required to migrate.
@Evert0x @Alexintosh @OpenZeppelin @VitalikButerin Satoshi: "I'm a proud father of three - my son Evert and two daughters."
@ameensol Does that mean that the rewards will be less if you initially minted + LPed 800 RAI, but due to IL you're now LPing <800 RAI?
@Evert0x @OpenZeppelin When are you going to put "OpenZeppelin contributor" in your bio?

5. 💥 Remove --args from CLI

Due to the added complexity of the bug fix, it is too error-prone to use the --args flag in the cashc CLI right now. 

Because of this, the flag has been removed, but will likely be reintroduced in the future.
@steve_fau @elonmusk https://t.co/oy51tijat0

3. 💥 Split compiler and SDK (cont'd)

It is still possible to compile your contracts programmatically by installing the cashc package separately.

Because we're not including the entire compiler in the CashScript SDK, the bundle size of the SDK is significantly smaller.
@fifikobayashi https://t.co/0h8OpcrfKc
@NFThub Sounds great, feel free to integrate it in any way you see fit! Would love to check it out when you integrated it 👌

3. 💥 Split compiler and SDK

The CashScript SDK used to export a CashCompiler object which could be used to compile contracts. 

The CLI should be used for this instead so that the compiled output can be put under version control and imported into the CashScript SDK.

@eviljordan @web3modal web3.js and ethers.js are javascript middleware libraries for Ethereum

they use web3-providers to call JSON-RPC methods on the nodes

some of those methods like eth_sendTransaction are signed by wallets

WalletConnect connects to a wallet remotely to sign it and return a tx hash

As most open-source projects we sustain ourselves through grants and donations 💵

Therefore in order to make it fair for everyone we want to include all integrations in our UI 📲

However this will include paging into the modal which will make the default ordering to hide some

@iamcrowne Smart Wallet is a smart contract wallet that allows interactions with multiple smart contracts in one transaction, compared to being limited to only one with a standard Ethereum account.

More specifically, it is the DSProxy, the proxy wallet developed and used by MakerDAO. (1/2)

2. The Nym network fills in the missing pieces for the cryptographic revolution.

Unlike Tor and Katzenpost/Meson, Nym uses blockchains in order not to have a central directory and uses incentives to decentralize the mix network.

More here: https://t.co/kgLvLf8vtu

Reasons to fund Nym:

1. The Nym team ships.

View our most recent release of the mix node on our github:
https://t.co/YQSeDc1k5H

Version 0.3.2 of the Nym mix node has been released and we have officially routed our first mixnet packets on the testnet as of today.

#PrivacyViaComputing

https://t.co/hkFnJNf6Bx

We have released version 0.2.0 of the mixnode, the NYM client, and the provider.

Client: https://t.co/ImiSb40aT9

Mixnode: https://t.co/1KTEA9VKwG

Provider:
https://t.co/XF8fl8lDgp

How mixnets compare to Tor and VPNs.

The NYM mixnet addresses the vulnerabilities for traffic analysis that the others do not by adding timing obfuscation, cover traffic, and multiple hops.

Learn more on how NYM is working to solve the privacy problem: https://t.co/kgLvLf8vtu https://t.co/WNiIf1OFyj

The way Nym provides stronger privacy than any single-use-case mixnet, and cryptographic primitives is due to our infrastructure supporting numerous applications that blend large, diverse user bases of different applications into a single massive crowd.

https://t.co/VnWzk5SLgZ https://t.co/IAJz63s8YX

For an overview on the basics of privacy tech, how mixnets function, and a workshop with the NYM team. Watch this recorded session with @futurechimp and @aniampiotrowska from @EFDevcon.

https://t.co/7vvHGDqFak

To achieve traffic analysis resistance against global network adversaries, the NYM mixnet generates cover traffic in the form of loop messages. 

The traffic loops strengthen anonymity and measure sender and receiver unobservability. https://t.co/QyYA2snYae
In order to be anonymous when using a mixnet, you must be indistinguishable amongst a group of users; the larger the group, the better the privacy. https://t.co/UKW8n8xDYe

Fund open-source development that is building towards a  privacy enhanced future by contributing to Nym's @Gitcoin grant.

https://t.co/0szAkJxyDG

As long as there's enough traffic flowing through the mixnodes, even an attacker who can record the entire internet will not be able to trace the packet flow through the Nym mixnet.

#AnonymityInNumbers

A node is removed if:

@PBWSummit @worldline @ja_akinyele @boltlabsinc @starkware @LabosNomades The confusion between zero-knowledge proofs and privacy continues to astound us. ZKPs are primarily used in Ethereum for scaling not privacy, and while they can do proofs of private values/computation, they don't actually hide anything from traffic analysis by NSA, your ISP...

If a node has dropped more than 50% of the measurement packets sent to it in the 24H leading to the report they will be removed from the network.

Following the 1 node per IP rule, we will manually remove all the nodes on the same machine keeping only one per IP with the highest reputation score.

Happy mixing y'all

There will be 2 sets of nodes in the 1500 set: 

    1) 'Active Set' nodes with the latest version installed with highest reputation score (>100) 
    2) 'Standbys' nodes with the latest version installed that are building reputation (<100)

@RGhadamian This is a Geth sync (eth1.0) only. For eth2.0 (staking) you would need a beacon chain and a validator (Prysm, Teku or Lighthouse clients).

@chrishobcroft @prylabs Yes. The new image will start syncing Geth (Goerli) and the beacon chain (connected locally to Geth) as systemd services. Same for the validator but you will need to perform a couple of tasks manually before starting the systemd service.
@domiodermatt That will work as well, yes. But I'm afraid the performance would be quite similar to the other setup. Take into account that the bottleneck is the same (the USB 3 port).

- Log into your Raspberry as ethereum user and create a validator account by running the command:

validator accounts create

- Copy the HEX deposit data. Go back to Prylabs portal and paste it into deposit data field

➖Eth2:  Working on Onyx and Witti testnets and creating an image with a step-by-step tutorial for participating on these networks. We already did some progress with Prysm, Teku and Lighthouse)

@TarekAdamMustaf We are working on this. We will release soon a new eth2 image along with a tutorial to run both the beacon chain and the validator.

@larsjaakko We use Ubuntu 64bit (for now) as it is pretty stable. You can download our image here:

@RGhadamian You need at last a Raspberry Pi 4 with 4 GB RAM and a decent USB SSD attached (500GB)
- For accessing the Grafana dashboards, open a browser and go to YOUR_RASBERRYPI_IP:3000 (admin:ethereum)

- Make the deposit
- Go back to your Raspberry Pi console, edit /etc/ethereum/prysm-validator.conf and set your validator account password.
- Start Prysm validator Systemd service by running

sudo systemctl start prysm-validator

Don’t create complex configurations such as disk RAIDS or HA solutions. Given the low penalties of going online it is not worth the risk of being slashed if something goes wrong with these kinds of configs.

So, if you get into trouble or go offline. Don't panic. Again, DON’T PANIC. You are good. Just grab a drink & try to figure out what is wrong. If you can’t, open an issue & ask the community . Remember that the penalties of going offline are ~ equal to being online.

Our @Raspberry_Pi 4 validator just made its first $ETH. What an incredible achievement.
 
5 years ago this was science fiction, so thanks to all researchers and devs that made it possible for a tiny board to be able to stake on the most advanced blockchain out there. #ethereum

By default it runs Geth, so, once the device is booted up, you are already syncing the Ethereum 1.0 blockchain. 

We disabled snap sync and snapshots new features in Geth for the time being until we get more info of how these new features impact the Raspberry Pi performance.
We will look into this soon...

If you want to update your #ethereum clients to their newest version, update your repos:
 
sudo add-apt-repository -r -n "deb https://t.co/MZdrZfEMLV bionic main"
sudo add-apt-repository -n "deb https://t.co/MZdrZfEMLV focal main"
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install $client

And by the way, we are running both #ethereum 1 and #ethereum 2 nodes in the same @Raspberry_Pi . So, when someone says to you that it is nearly impossible to run an Ethereum node, remember this tweet.

Last, but not least, we are very grateful for your @gitcoin grants contributions and the @EF_ESP grants support. We really appreciate it.

https://t.co/M69JWqYYqH

Ok, we just tried a fresh #ethereum Geth sync on a @Raspberry_Pi 4.
 
It took 29 hours to sync the whole blockchain with the new snap sync mode.
 
This is an amazing sync time but we think it will improve a little in a few weeks. Some data 👇 https://t.co/RNjxcRFXEJ

Geth: 1.10.1
Cache: default (geth sets it to 2.6 GB)
Geth params: --metrics --metrics.expensive --pprof --http --syncmode snap
Sync time: 29 hours
Blockchain size: 295 GB

Export the slashing database from your old client and import it into the new one. All clients implemented this feature so it is a matter of finding the proper commands (and docs are pretty straightforward).

In your old client (if you keep the same node running), disable the systemd validator service (if any) and move or rename the validator directory. Remember that running the same keys in 2 different clients / places at once is the most common slashing event.

- Run a backup device with an Eth1 node and the Beacon Chain synced. If something goes wrong you can easily switch to it.
- Remember that you can use 3rd party providers such as @infura_io if you are not able to sync an Eth1 or Eth2 nodes on time

- Jump into Eth teams discords or open a bug on Github if something goes wrong (missed attestations, missed blocks, low peers, etc) and don’t hesitate to ask for info. Even if your question seems dumb to you it may be a bug or other important issue.

- As complex setups can get you slashed. For instance, do not enable the validator systemd service or any other kind of automatic start.
- Run an UPS to avoid data corruption (more than going offline).

9/ #ConvictionVoting mimics distributed processes in nature, like neurons firing in the brain after they charge up adequate action potential. Could this vote streaming tool bring us closer to real-time collective intelligence...? https://t.co/88Uc2Lw9pu

11/ This is a new governance tool and the design space is wide open for further exploration. This suggests there could be multiple “flavors” of Conviction Voting, with different applications: https://t.co/aR969e9QW0

5/ So...what is #ConvictionVoting? It's a new decision making process where voters can continuously express their preference by staking tokens in support of proposals they like. You could consider it kind of like "vote streaming". https://t.co/AYT4UPf3yk
Thanks @tjayrush and @trueblocks for being one of our long-time contributors! 🤩

16/ Digital twins can also be used to provide operational decision support for communities:
- 📐 During their design stage
- 📊 In their continuous governance

And establish the foundations for Computer Aided Governance 🦾

https://t.co/6eBAbYPCVI

1/ Announcing the #ConvictionVoting cadCAD Model Release: Understanding Real-Time ‘Vote Streaming'

https://t.co/nTmAhNMDE2

New blog post and a thread! 🧵👇

1/ The results are in! Our first Conviction Voting pilot is awarding the Top 15 projects - as voted on by our community - with ~89x grant matching from @PanvalaHQ                                                              
https://t.co/jQOQ20uEE7

12/ A. Conviction Funding: Proposals have a discrete 'passing' threshold. When group conviction exceeds the threshold, funds are disbursed. Examples include the @1Hiveorg or @CommonsStack patterns, which are distributed work proposal systems that allocate DAO funds. https://t.co/wjFiLzzrTt

4/ New voting tools, enabled by blockchain technology, can provide communities with rich data streams of continuous preference signals from their members, rather than getting a mere "snapshot" of their opinions through a regular time-boxed voting process. https://t.co/eWpM0x641B

1/ Check out this interactive @kumupowered graph of all 'Praise' that has been dished at the Commons Stack! 

Much praise to @danilolessa for putting this together 🙏

https://t.co/AIKGssePtW https://t.co/K7urk8TxNc

15/ Why Model CV in @cadCAD_org? Because digital twins help us understand and manage complex systems. Think of them like digital flight simulators. They can be used to run your system through many different “scenarios” to see what effects may throw your system out of balance. https://t.co/KG7fJwnOQf

13/ B. Conviction Consensus: Proposals are continuous, reflecting a ‘dynamic average consensus' of the group. An example could be a community parameter (such as an exit tax rate) that is dynamically set based on the averaged continual input of members. https://t.co/8zhlZsDAu5

8/ Conviction Voting mitigates:
🚫 Governance control by majority holders
🚫 Last minute vote swings
🚫 Low voter participation due to short voting windows

17/ Now that you have some context, check out the #ConvictionVoting @cadcad_org model, a digital twin of the @1Hiveorg DAO ecosystem:

https://t.co/XSpr7aJf8N

10/ CV has foundations in the PhD research of @mZargham in robotics & multi-agent coordination systems - where it was called "Social Sensor Fusion," a continuous ‘fusion’ of individual opinions into a collective sentiment signal. 

https://t.co/9QzDtG3Oay
5/ A huge thank you to all those who took part in our first Conviction Voting pilot! 🙏 Stay tuned for more CV research & experiments to come.

7/ Conviction Voting improves:
✔️ Distributed decision making
✔️ Turning evolving social needs into coordinated action
✔️ Insight into collective community intent

6/ This allows people to weigh-in anytime & eliminates the need for group consensus on every proposal. It moves away from majoritarian decision making, and  towards sufficient support for proposals in real-time - a novel way to manage shared resources as a commons. 💡🌱

2/ The TEC is building a token economy based on the 🐝 @1Hiveorg Gardens template and a bonding curve that feeds into a #ConvictionVoting DAO. Read more about the kickoff here:

 https://t.co/rqRbvePbO2

18/ If you would rather follow along with a video explainer, check out this model walkthrough by @aclarkdata1 & @jeffemmett:

https://t.co/YXfVSV9l31

19/ Thanks for reading! 🙏 If you want to support more work on #ConvictionVoting and improved CV model features, consider contributing $PAN or $DAI to this grant, which receives additional funds through quadratic matching: 

 https://t.co/bE8lSeLVtl

14/ Note: CV is not intended to supplant traditional voting in a representative democracy, but rather grow our democratic toolbox to empower communities experimenting with direct democracy & token-based voting systems.

Progress must be incremental, modeled & tested. 👩‍🔬

Data #Persistence: Global pinning has been added to #ethswarm Beta. This feature makes the local pinners of content discoverable and offers a recovery protocol for data chunks if they are not available in the neighbourhood they originally belong to. https://t.co/pNi2IJ9oo9

Privacy - content on #ethswarm can be encrypted before it's sent to the network. In order to retrieve the plain text, the swarm address, as well as the decryption key must be provided. This is just one of the many new #swarmbeta features. See the demo: https://t.co/OlIfHeq5xJ

Name resolution is added to #ethswarm Beta. Now you can navigate with human-readable names, such as ENS. This is just one of the many exciting new Swarm features. Come to the Beta event for more info. Watch the demo: https://t.co/6TeBIS6PHO

8/18 The value of data comes with interoperability between different systems. @personium is working on connecting Japan’s information banking with #ethswarm. Excited to create a bridge to enable interoperability. Congratulations! More info: https://t.co/OCsVtUmvMj #WeAreAllSwarm

18/18 This rounds up the fabulous group of first #ethswarm grant recipients. Hopefully these projects also inspire you to make your ideas happen on Swarm. Those who missed this call, fear not, next wave of #ethswarm grants will be announced at Swarm Beta: https://t.co/Tts3dyZoNa

6/18 dApps building on #ethswarm need a stable, secure authentication solution, where the data belongs exclusively to the user. @GetLoginEth is working on this and we are happy to support their work. Congratulations! More info: https://t.co/OCsVtUmvMj #WeAreAllSwarm
The second workshop of today with @FairDataSociety about how to develop unstoppable dApps on #ethswarm starts in 30 mins. Join link: https://t.co/3jxSj0jjlb #ComeTogether #Ethereum

12/18 Web archive + Swarm = Bee Archive. First, step: save websites to Swarm with a chrome extension. Imagine having an immutable archive. Could be quite call in the times of fake news. Congratulations! More info: https://t.co/OCsVtUmvMj #WeAreAllSwarm

15/18 What happens on a festival, stays on a festival. Especially if you use Boma app (ticket sale, program schedule, etc) on #ethswarm to ensure their user’s privacy and data ownership. Dance like nobody is watching. Congratulations! More info: https://t.co/OCsVtUmvMj

3/18 Bladerunner DAO is going to store their users’ data on #ethswarm. Data will be stored in a private way and belong to the users alone. As it should. Congratulations to @TheUpala team, we're happy to support you with a grant. More info: https://t.co/OCsVtUmvMj #WeAreAllSwarm

4/18 #ethswarm is a perfect solution for storing videos and permissionless publishing. For this reason it’s exciting to see @Etherna_io building a transparent video platform and building databases on top of Swarm. Congratulations! More info: https://t.co/OCsVtUmvMj #WeAreAllSwarm

Here are all the details about our 2nd workshop hosted by the amazing @FairDataSociety on 28th Sept at 13:30 as part of the Swarm Beta release event. #ComeTogether and let's buidl some #dApps! #ethswarm #Ethereum 
https://t.co/8gFZh7CzJ7

5/18 People will soon be able to manage and share their signed documents in a trust-less manner from the comfort of their homes. #XDV is doing it on #ethswarm, assuring the privacy and security of their data. Congratulations! More info: https://t.co/OCsVtUmvMj #WeAreAllSwarm

13/18 Art is timeless and inspires new ideas.@egorkraft is preparing an art installation called “Twelve nodes of Fair data principles” to start discussions about shared ethical values of the fair data economy. Congratulations. More info: https://t.co/OCsVtUmvMj #WeAreAllSwarm

16/18 A #ethswarm grant was given also to the amazing @Givethio for making their first steps towards building their dApp on #ethswarm. A small step towards the first milestone, a giant leap towards decentralised giving. Congratulations! More info: https://t.co/OCsVtUmvMj

11/18 What would web3 without memes look like? We don’t even want to know, so we are happy to approve a grant to make this possible. Congratulations to the Meme-generator team for receiving the #ethswarm grant! More info: https://t.co/OCsVtUmvMj #WeAreAllSwarm

10/18 Web3 needs a spam-free, secure and decentralized email service on top of #ethswarm.  #Waggle is working on this and we can’t wait to see the first results of their work. Congratulations on receiving the Swarm grant. More info: https://t.co/OCsVtUmvMj #WeAreAllSwarm

7/18 #Zetaseek’s approach to a search engine that will be used by each user separately is really a fresh and interesting use case of what can be done with #ethswarm. Congrats on the grant, can’t wait for the first demo videos.  More info: https://t.co/OCsVtUmvMj #WeAreAllSwarm

14/18 Swarm network is a public good for self-sovereign digital society.. @TRIResearch_ proposed "Swarm and the potential for a Data Commons" research and the rest will be in public domain. Congratulations! More info: https://t.co/OCsVtUmvMj #WeAreAllSwarm

#ethswarm is hiring! Join the team creating the future of decentralised storage and communication. See our #Jobs page for details, RT for karma tokens <3 https://t.co/WT31Hac8BE

Bee-clef is a newly released package by the #ethswarm team, which works together with the Bee node to increase the security and interoperability of your Swarm account. If you are running a Bee node, it's recommended to install bee-clef first and Bee after. https://t.co/auwXcl3mAx

Arbitrum outage tldr:
👉 sending L2 txs via sequencer was not possible
👉 users could force any tx via Ethereum L1 (ex. funds withdrawal)
👉 funds were never at risk

This is exactly why we care about L2s -- in the worst case, it's still Ethereum 🔥🔥🔥

@smpalladino @Amxx @DanFinlay3 @metamask_io @gitcoin @TabooKeyNet Right. That's precisely what RelayHub does. If a contract is called and msg.sender == RelayHub, the contract can depend on having the real sender appended to the data. It's abstracted by getSender. Returns msg.sender unless it's from RelayHub, in which case it returns the signer.

>>> minted_dai = dai_contract.functions.totalSupply().call() / 10**18
>>> dsr_dai = pot_contract.functions.Pie().call() * pot_contract.functions.chi().call() / 10**45
>>> dsr_dai / (minted_dai + dsr_dai)

How to settle the "money is hard tech" vs "money is a social construct" debate:

Money is both, but hard tech is a prerequisite to becoming a social construct.

Say we discover a small supply of a new gold-like metal. It will have value, but it won't reach gold's market cap.

I think there is a need to draw a line between:

+ DeFi (decentralised finance)
+ DeCo (decentralised commerce)

The former is about trading, lending, market making and derivatives, while the latter is about payments, subscriptions, invoicing and shopping.

A governance token gets its intrinsic value from at least two sources:

💸 The prospect that the token may start accruing protocol fees someday
🗳️ The extent to which third parties derive benefits from having more voting power

The price is not pumped by mere speculation.

1️⃣ Use checks-effects-interactions
2️⃣ Wrap the transfer functions in a "require"

5️⃣ Write an emergency withdrawal function for third-parties

@nicksdjohnson I record hash+nonce, fetch the tx receipt, if not present,I check the nonce at a final block (on mainnet i use current block - 12) if the nonce is greater than the tx one, then I assume the tx has been cancelled or replaced.
you can see it in action on https://t.co/o7H1KtJxRZ

More evidence that systemic change (on the scale that we need) is unlikely to come from our legacy institutions. Although often well intentioned, in practice they are incapable of upgrading themselves.

Not only do we need change - we need to change *how* we change things.

Amazing how important it is to establish widespread demand for currency use. Almost like they're recognized as a tool for large scale coordination (or, on their shadow side, control.)

Perhaps we should democratize these powerful tools to mitigate their dangerous misuse.

Stay humble, be vulnerable, keep learning.

⚙️ Conviction Voting (CV) will be used to determine which TEC proposals to fund.  It is a decision-making process that takes into account both the number of tokens voting on a proposal and the time they’re held on it.

WARNING: these are the only valid addresses for baby USM, on the Ethereum mainnet network. Do not send mainnet ETH to last week's kovan testnet addresses!

The main baby USM contract is at https://t.co/Gs6HwRDggy. The FUM contract is at https://t.co/fRloj8PkSF. And there's a proxy contract at https://t.co/Z915EyN9s0 for if you prefer to send/receive WETH.

Baby USM is just like the full USM version coming in January, except:
- Max 1 ETH per tx
- Max 100 ETH total in the contract (40 today, increasing daily)
- Becomes withdraw-only after Jan 15
USM is still new and risky. Please double-check your steps or you may lose your money, as happened in this case. https://t.co/I1BpkplUa4

But the SIMPLEST way to interact with it is by just sending it tokens:
- Send KETH to USM contract: receive USM tokens (aka mint)
- Send KETH to FUM contract: receive FUM tokens (fund)
- Send USM to either contract: receive KETH (burn)
- Send FUM to either: receive KETH (defund)
We welcome contributions towards the audit and other expenses - BIG THANK YOU to those who've helped us get this far! https://t.co/9H8xkDfqu5
USM is now feature-complete and edging towards release. Last chance to help us out with corrections/improvements! Once it's launched it's too late... https://t.co/q5kVxB8cDs
Again, even with the capped pool this is real money, so please be careful and don't go overboard... This is still quite raw code...

Money costs money! Can you spare a dime towards completion of USM's security audit? https://t.co/9H8xkDfqu5

Usage/fee tips:
1. You'll need to increase the gas limit to 120k or so: these are not simple 21k ETH transfers.
(Thanks to @musatheredguard for the idea of staging our launch this way. Because the contracts will be immutable, we really want to work out the kinks now.)
As everyone knows by now a single audit only proves so much, but it was reassuring that they didn't find anything really heinous. (OK except a couple... Which we fixed)

Check out how to buy and sell Kovan USM and FUM using only your wallet!

-Send Ether to the USM contract to buy USM
-Send Ether to the FUM contract to buy FUM
-Send USM to the USM or FUM contracts to sell USM
-Send FUM to the USM or FUM contracts to sell FUM https://t.co/kEdeyAKVzI
And final reminder that you have LESS THAN 24 HOURS to help with our audit expenses in Gitcoin round 8! https://t.co/9H8xkDfqu5
Say hello to... "baby USM"! Deployed today, baby USM is a temporary (1-month), capped-supply, but *real-money* version of the USM stablecoin/contract. https://t.co/VzZ7YWJmgx

We invite you to try all four operations!
- mint: send ETH to USM contract, get back USM stablecoin tokens
- fund: sent ETH to FUM contract, get FUM (non-stable, "funding") tokens
- burn: send USM to USM or FUM contract, get ETH
- defund: send FUM to either contract, get ETH
2. An early version of the USM system is UP ON KOVAN TESTNET! Please do play with it & report any suggestions/bugs. Here's how...

A couple of big @usmfum updates -

1. Our security audit, by @SolidifiedHQ, is complete! You can check it out at: https://t.co/mbJrzrmedg
Reminder: kovan is a *testnet*! DO NOT SEND REAL MAINNET ETH TO EITHER OF THESE ADDRESSES! Also testnet tokens are unlikely to make you rich sheesh...
(We deleted tweets here that referred to the kovan contract addresses, to prevent confusion with the newer "baby USM" mainnet addresses. See: https://t.co/8ShqxFkQoO)
You can get a better price (gas aside...) by breaking down your operation into smaller operations: eg, five 0.2-ETH mints instead of one 1-ETH mint.

The main baby USM contract is at https://t.co/Gs6HwRDggy. The FUM contract is at https://t.co/fRloj8PkSF. And there's a proxy contract at https://t.co/Z915EyN9s0 for if you prefer to send/receive WETH.
3. Fees are also increased by recent activity: if a bunch of people just bought FUM, buying FUM will be pricey. You can expect a good price if no one else has bought/sold in the last 5-10 min.
One way to get some kovan KETH is via the faucet at https://t.co/y6sMys0sGo.

Learning how software version control works is not useful only if you're a programmer - anyone working in tech should know the basics.

Git is a fundamental shift in how information is tracked and updated over time.

6/ Closely related to documentation is code linting and formatting.

A linter helps you adhere to best practices, while a formatter makes your code more readable.

At Hifi, we use my Solidity template, which has a Solhint and Prettier setup.

https://t.co/en4BclaAu4

11/ Stay on top of trends and be a good open-source citizen.

Check out new tools, articles, papers and books, and share what you learn on public knowledge forums like StackExchange.

I discovered many now-essential tools for Hifi this way.

https://t.co/qjG6ZOXGBw

Hey @CopperLaunch, how do we delist auction "0x174cfa15a24f3fc49fc2bc66b5e6046e549557c9"?

It's ripping people off.

8/ Take care of your deployment pipeline.

Contracts that have been deployed to the blockchain should be easily identifiable in your repo.

Tag your commits, create GitHub releases, keep a CHANGELOG, and ship your node packages to a public registry. https://t.co/68sIAj14tm
I'll keep shilling custom errors until every Solidity developer I know starts using them instead of revert reason strings.

9/ Minimize complexity and follow community standards.

Order (almost) everything alphabetically to lessen the cognitive load on your colleagues.

Follow the Conventional Commits convention to create an explicit commit history.

Here are the latest commits in the Hifi monorepo: https://t.co/ggQTBzID8s

4/ Low code coverage is an omen for future bugs.

Some devs brush off coverage as something that takes a lot of time and yields little benefit.

But that comes mostly from web2 folks.

In web3, you're writing mission-critical scripts (aka smart contracts).

Aim for 100% coverage. https://t.co/eFmjXKqVTs

7/ Keep your contracts small, and declutter them by packaging the general-purpose parts as separate libraries (this is what I did with PRBMath).

If your project is very big, consider switching to a monorepo.

Hifi is maintained as a yarn workspaces monorepo. https://t.co/hJHRESfe1Z

#DFGC が扱っている $TXJP トークンについてフォーカスして紹介しました。

コミュニティの 1st Dapps が 日本円等価トークン発行アプリケーション @YamatoProtocol ⛰になりますのでこちらも併せてフォローいただければ嬉しいです。

DEXで交換できるということは当然 相場があります。
各サイトで $TXJP トークンアドレス「0x961dd84059505d59f82ce4fb87d3c09bec65301d」を入れると確認することができます。

https://t.co/gM67zGZRYV
https://t.co/jG2HFrCtwJ
https://t.co/6xoQZeii7s

参考価格（9/16 16:00現在　1枚118$）
#DFGC

DeFiGeek Community JAPANのメンバーがついに1000人を突破しました！

コミュニティは記念すべきDeFiDapps第一弾@yamatoprotocol のテストネットに向けて準備中です！

今後も日本を代表するDeFiDapps構築チームを目指していきます！

#Yamato $YMT $CJPY #DFGC $TXJP https://t.co/SWdlJgDHXj

ツイッターの壁紙用に1500×500サイズにリメイクしました。
自由にご利用ください。
#DFGC  #Yamato  $TXJP  $YMT  $CJPY https://t.co/HA6TJ71vGz

$TXJP ホルダーには特典があります。
一例として $YMT トークンのエアドロップ予定です。
いわゆるガバナンストークンで、#DFGC で開発している日本円等価トークン発行アプリケーションYamato protocolに対応するものです。
現在テストネットに向けて開発進行中。

概説記事:
https://t.co/cgD8ikNbNJ

#DFGC が扱っているトークンの1つに $TXJP があります。
これは主に寄付イベントへの参加や開発・広報活動などコミュニティ貢献者に対して付与しているものです。

Imagine doing complex swaps with a single message signature on Metamask.

No need to do multiple approvals.

No need to pay ETH for approvals/swap.

Just sign a SINGLE message to execute it all.

Hoping that EIP-3074 goes live this October so we can make this a reality 💪 https://t.co/AmghZam1Lf

In tokenized vesting model, each vesting schedule is represented by an NFT.

Any address that holds the vesting position NFT can claim the vested rewards.

You can also trade your vesting position NFT with others. After the transfer, the new owner claims the vested rewards.

When you buy/sell anything from primary or secondary markets, you are usually using (on/off-chain) orderbooks.

Every asset on these orderbooks has it's own price set by the seller & buying/selling assets on an orderbook does NOT affect the price of any other asset (no slippage).
@0xZoo @genie_xyz Not fully ready for public access yet 🙃

@0xPEPO @0xmons @alexgausman @Scott_eth Each of these categories have their own challenges.

1. pfps: Pricing (Moderately hard). Lending (Moderately hard)

2. utility nfts: pricing (Simple), Lending (Simple)

3. Art: pricing (Very hard), Lending (Very hard)

4. Defi NFTs: pricing (Very Simple), Lending (Very Simple)

@RealCrypto420 What platform do you use to buy/sell stuff?

In such cases @genie_xyz handles the slippage calculation for you 🙌

For eg, when I try to buy a Meebits from NFTX, you can see the price updates automatically (according to the slippage) and the list of NFTs is dynamically sorted according to the lowest price filters 🔥 https://t.co/P5auhv0dIS

We also manage the slippage for you on the sell side 😎

Let's say, you are trying to sell 2 Meebits. We search for the best bids (on orderbooks) and the best prices (for AMM-based markets), and sell on different orderbooks and pools to get the maximum return for you 🚀

2/

In some cases there is a huge difference in the price of the same asset listed on different platforms.

Here is an example of #6192 listed on OpenSea (50 ETH) and the same #6192 listed on Rarible (10 ETH). 

You can see that Genie fetches the cheaper (10 ETH) option for you. https://t.co/jSnS7ZmgVR

While testing @genie_xyz internally, a few things I observed that are solved by Genie 👇

1/

A lot of people are NOT aware that they can sell (at floor) on NFTX, NFT20. 

Here is an example of OpenSea sell orders (0.209 ETH) lower than the floor price on NFTX (~0.228 ETH). https://t.co/oG9K5y6v8k

GenieSwap addresses these market inefficiencies by: 

1. Automatically selling for the best price for you across multiple markets, including any AMM slippage (routing your order across multiple markets). 

2. Finding the cheapest price for an asset listed on any market.

NFT+DeFi market is diverse.

1. Primary Markets
2. Secondary Markets
3. NFT Exchanges
4. ERC20 Exchanges
5. Synthetic Markets (soon)

Some markets (3,4) have slippage and some don't (1,2).

Don't worry, @genie_xyz manages all the dirty work for you 🙂

Let's see how 👇 https://t.co/7DpKxpDfcV

So, in the example here we can see that when I select some Meebits to buy from OpenSea, you don't see any change in the prices (see prices at the bottom of each card).

Hence no slippage 🙂 https://t.co/lxRD0DmFDi

When I want to buy/sell some assets on Fractionalized NFT markets like NFTX, NFT20, etc. we have to use AMM markets like UniSwap, SushiSwap under the hood to buy/sell fractions of NFTs.

This means that each NFT that you sell/buy on NFTX, NFT20 changes the prices on the pools.

Week 3 involved us starting to prepare for formalizing our KB3 Adventure, as Expo Day neared. We asked mentors about community building and what it takes to create a loyal community (you!)

Due to the multi-step procedure for initially starting a loan with PawnSpace, we realized it would be costly for users to transact on Ethereum Mainnet. This had led us to explore alternative Layer 2 scaling solutions such as @0xPolygon  earlier this year in January.
As we keep building PawnSpace, we want to also emphasize community-building, as we know that at the end of the day it is you the community who will use our protocol, and validate what we are doing.

⛰ Today at MCON, @owocki announced the 🎉 tip party app built by the 🚀 moonshot collective.

💸 It's a way to distribute tokens to a group over a call (or an audience at a talk).

https://t.co/WdDKSTVjYN

Pick up the "Aging Whole Earth Catalog" to get an NFT that begins to "age" as soon as you unwrap it. 

Over the next 100 years the NFT's appearance will change in your wallet. 🌎😍

One of the first coordination/funding tools to come out of 🚀moonshot is called 🎉 tip party!

It’s a great way for us to yolo a few GTC to builders on a call, but thanks to dogfooding it also emerged as a handy way to quickly gather a list of folks’ ENS addresses for other apps!

4/ 如果已有进行中的交易，长时间未被打包也未提示丢弃，如何发起下一笔交易？

打开 metamask 设置 -> 高级 -> 自定义交易 nonce，启用，发送下一笔交易时，可以手动编辑 nonce，nonce 的值与进行中交易的 nocne 一致即可。

2/ 在 metamask 中配置 Flashbots RPC

选择 Custom RPC 添加网络，正确填写以下信息（仅适用于以太坊主网）。

网络名称: Flashbots RPC
新增 RPC URL: https://t.co/AQNqsGsPsx
链 ID: 1
Currency Symbol: ETH

https://t.co/uY0UwIC7lp

5/ 一般钱包中取消交易的原理，也是通过覆盖 nonce 的方式发起一笔 self 交易（向自己转一笔 0 eth 的交易）。

每个地址的 nonce 都是从 0 开始，当 nonce 为 0 的交易处理完之后，才会处理 nonce 为 1 的交易，依次累加；修改 nocne 为 metamask 高级功能，若不理解 nonce 的含义，请谨慎使用。

:)

3/ 检查 metamask 是否正确选择 Flashbots RPC 网络

通过 Flashbots RPC 网络发送交易，长时间未被打包会被丢弃；这时需要注意的是，如果有进行中的交易，不能切换网络至以太坊主网，否则会将交易发送给以太坊主网的 RPC 节点，导致失败交易被打包，从而浪费 gas。

#flashbots #flashnft

pro tip: 如何正确使用 Flashbots?

1/ 通过 Flashbots 发送交易时，只有交易成功时才支付矿工费，更节约交易成本。

可以减少在 Uniswap Dex 上兑换被夹的可能（当前版本 v0.4，交易未隐私，仍可以被 relayer 和矿工看到）；避免在 Opensea 扫地板时被别人抢先扫掉，交易 reverted 仍然需要支付 gas。

Why?
The current generation of DeFi protocols has brought unprecedented levels of programmability and automation. 

We believe the next wave will focus on intelligence as a core capability. 

This is a perfect challenge for the Scaleout team!

What?
The goal of the UniCast project is to publish a v1 of a model that predicts volatility in Uniswap v3 trading pairs. 

This can be used to find the Uniswap v3 LP ranges that maximises fees, and thereby makes Uniswap v3 LPing incredibly more capital efficient.
If this sounds exciting, please consider supporting our project here 🙏🤗: https://t.co/iX6H4s3Tla
All of this will be provided for free to use as open source with templates that can be forked, copied, improved and used as starting points for any number of other machine learning projects in web3.

The UniCast repo is now public here:
https://t.co/L1N6yD1vZZ

#ML  #Web3  #DeFi https://t.co/lKihserIPY

Uniswap v3 is a great leap forward in automated market making with concentrated liquidity and multiple fee tiers. 

However, it introduces a lot of complexity for the users.  It’s hard to figure out what ranges, what pairs, and what duration to use creating an optimal strategy.

But it doesn't stop there! The project will also provide: 
- the tools, 
- building blocks, 
- and examples 
to build, train and serve machine learning predictions for off-chain or on-chain use using Python and other tools. 

And the best part...

Announcing our @gitcoin grant!! 👀📢

Come and support the UniCast project here 🙏✨ https://t.co/iX6H4s3Tla

#GR11 #ethereum #UniswapV3 #DeFi 

Learn more. A thread...🧵👇 https://t.co/ReQPIm9gZj

An example:
A user might set a target time frame of 30 days and a probability range of 90%. This means that the model will give a prediction for a LP range where the price is within the LP range 90% of the time over the coming 30 days.

In March, we launched https://t.co/omDeOAGHBn, our private payments protocol.

It demonstrates how Aztec's privacy architecture can enable simple asset transfers, allowing users to privately send $DAI, $ETH, and $renBTC.

Over 20,000 users have deposited $38 million+.

Aztec batches like transactions among users of the network and passes them to an Aztec Bridge Contract:

The Bridge Contract is a 50 to 100-line interface allowing Aztec's roll-up to interact with a given Layer 1 protocol.

For the first time ever, it's now possible to interact cheaply and privately with any Ethereum DeFi application.

Better yet, Aztec Connect's functionality enhances the network's privacy guarantees:
https://t.co/XEolWy4ZXC

Aztec Connect, the first private bridge for Ethereum DeFi, is live on testnet.

Up to 100x gas savings with fully private transactions by default.

Private DeFi is here. https://t.co/d7RedFHmIK

Due to its simplicity and robustness, integrating with Aztec has significant benefits over other solutions:

- Full privacy for users.
- No liquidity fragmentation 
- Up to 100x gas savings
- No redeployment of core contracts - just a 50–100 line bridge contract

The Bridge Contract then takes the aggregated funds and calls the relevant functions from a DeFi protocol.

Proceeds from the interaction are returned to the rollup contract.

You can think of the Bridge as a proxy sitting on Ethereum that represents users on Aztec.

An operator directing batched Aztec funds to the right DeFi protocols, giving users:

- 10x cheaper transactions
- Full privacy

@ChrisBlec The next phase of our decentralisation plan is to add a time-delay when changing verification keys.

This removes the ability to quickly hotfix issues, we want to wait until the tech is more mature before doing this.
@0xYeeeew @cryptoMaxi420 @jonwu_ @SwagtimusP We will clarify the distinction between permissionless contracts and whitelisted front-end inclusion going forward.

@ChrisBlec We have a multisig contract that is able to change the verification keys used to verify rollup proofs.

Our cryptography is extremely cutting edge and our position is that the ability to quickly fix any bugs or security issues in our cryptographic circuits is extremely important.

@ChrisBlec If a malicious actor got control of the multisig they could upload a key for a circuit that would allow them to print zk notes and steal user funds.

This would require the attacker to deploy some extremely advanced cryptography in addition to controlling the multisig.
@unclebutta Any protocol or community member can permissionlessly build a Bridge Contract to connect to Aztec 😉

@imrane The cost of proof verification is amortized across all transactions (and many use cases). Users of a specific Defi interaction split the cost of just that interaction. Think of it like getting privacy for free, then group-buying a defi transaction.
